Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Academic Scholars Program is awarding 15 annual scholarships that average $7,000 per academic year to academically talented, but financially needy, students majoring in Biology, Chemistry, and Mathematics. Outreach efforts focus on women and minorities underrepresented in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields. Activities are designed and implemented to support the Academic Scholars Program as a whole, including efforts to expand and institutionalize this program. Scholarship recipients move through each phase of their educational programs as a cohort, but also receive personalized encouragement and support through an ongoing relationship with their Academic Scholars Mentor.

Intellectual Merit: The Academic Scholars program builds upon the framework developed for the prior S-STEM project (0631133) and incorporates the lessons learned during the successful management of that project as well as utilizing a comprehensive evaluation process to improve success. Successful program components include:
(a) The utilization of Individual Education Plans for each scholarship recipient as well as an Academic Scholars Mentor who monitors academic progress.
(b) The creation of a STEM student cohort through the College Success Center.
(c) The participation of scholarship recipients in field experiences which offer application-oriented experiences.
(d) Increased collaboration between faculty and students in STEM disciplines.

Broader Impact: The Academic Scholars Program is critical in advancing the knowledge and understanding of science, engineering, technology and mathematics in an Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI) campus comprised of highly diverse, economically disadvantaged, and academically talented students. This program is broadening opportunities and enabling participation for underrepresented groups of students to pursue degrees in STEM disciplines. The outcomes from the program objectives are being broadly disseminated in order that other colleges may replicate the program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Phoenix College (PC) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) Program, titled the Academic Scholars Program (ASP), provided robust support, both academic and financial, for students majoring in biology, chemistry, or mathematics from Fall 2012 to Spring 2019.  Supports included a scholarship award of $3,500 per semester for up to four semesters, cohort experiences, authentic experiences such as internships and access to undergraduate research, faculty mentoring, peer mentoring, a student support coordinator to match students up with services such as tutoring or counseling, and content related field trips.  At the conclusion of this program, 93% achieved success (as defined subsequently) compared with 75% of control students, statistically significant difference with the odds of success 4.32 times higher for students participating in the S-STEM ASP cohort.  Additionally, students' progress rate (measured as credits earned per semester) was significantly higher on average after joining the program. 

The PC ASP program ran from the Fall of 2012 to the Spring of 2019 awarding scholarships to 64 distinct students.  The ethnicity and gender distributions of the cohort are included in figures 1 and 2 below.  The cohort consisted of 56% female students and 76% from ethnicity groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM disciplines.

For the success analysis a matched control group was found for the cohort group.  Control students were matched to the cohort group by STEM major, age group, gender, ethnicity, and credit hours earned.  At the conclusion of the program, 53 cohort students (93%) achieved success by completing a degree, transferring to a university, or continued enrollment in the subsequent semester, compared to 48 students (75%) in the control group, a statistically significant difference in proportions.  The odds of success were 4.32 times higher for students participating in the S-STEM ASP cohort than for a matched control group. 

All excepting two S-STEM ASP admitted students had attended college prior to program entry; average number of terms attended was 4.283.  Thus, an analysis was undertaken to understand how the program intervention affected their progress.  On average, students' progress rate (measured as credits earned per semester) was higher after joining the program (approximately 14 credits per term) than before joining the program (approximately 12 credits per term), this increase in credit hours earned per semester was significant.

The PC ASP S-STEM program, evidenced a positive impact on student success, and degree progress.  At the conclusion of the program 93% of students had achieved success compared with 75% of control students, a statistically significant difference with the odds of success 4.32 times higher for students participating in the S-STEM ASP cohort.  Progress rate towards a degree was also significantly higher on average after joining the program.  The PC S-STEM program was designed utilizing research that suggested cohort interactions, mentoring, and authentic hands-on experiences such as undergraduate research, increase measures of success and retention in STEM fields.  These increases in completion and success were also seen, sometimes at higher rates, in traditionally underrepresented student populations.  The previously provided evidence of the PC ASP S-STEM program efficacy builds on and supports existing literature in this area, and is applicable to populations traditionally underrepresented in STEM.
